entities.name: ANCIENT CIVILIZATIONS
entities.description: Ancient civilizations such as Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece, where homes served as centers of social, political, and religious life

entities.name: MESOPOTAMIA
entities.description: Ancient civilization where homes were more than just shelters, serving as centers of social, political, and religious life

entities.name: EGYPT
entities.description: Ancient civilization where homes were more than just shelters, serving as centers of social, political, and religious life

entities.name: GREECE
entities.description: Ancient civilization where homes were more than just shelters, serving as centers of social, political, and religious life

entities.name: MANOR HOUSE
entities.description: Large estate in the Middle Ages where noble families lived and governed their lands, often fortified and featuring elaborate architecture

entities.name: INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION
entities.description: Period that brought significant changes in home building and organization, leading to more standardized and affordable housing for the middle class

entities.name: LE CORBUSIER
entities.description: Architect who championed modernist design principles, emphasizing simplicity, functionality, and efficiency in home design

entities.name: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT
entities.description: Architect who championed modernist design principles, emphasizing simplicity, functionality, and efficiency in home design

entities.name: LUDWIG MIES VAN DER ROHE
entities.description: Architect who championed modernist design principles, emphasizing simplicity, functionality, and efficiency in home design

entities.name: LEVITTOWN
entities.description: First planned suburban community in the United States, setting the standard for mass-produced housing with its cookie-cutter design and affordable prices

entities.name: SMART TECHNOLOGY
entities.description: Technology that equips homes with interconnected devices and systems, allowing homeowners to control and monitor various aspects of their home remotely

entities.name: SUSTAINABLE DESIGN PRACTICES
entities.description: Practices in home design and construction that aim to reduce environmental impact and create healthier living environments, including energy-efficient materials and green building techniques

entities.name: SUBURBAN HOME
entities.description: Type of home that became popular in the post-World War II period, characterized by mass-produced, affordable housing in planned communities

entities.name: SMART HOME
entities.description: Home equipped with interconnected devices and systems that allow for remote control and monitoring of various aspects of the home

entities.name: SUSTAINABLE HOME
entities.description: Home designed and constructed using sustainable practices to reduce environmental impact and create healthier living environments

entities.name: PASSIVE SOLAR DESIGN
entities.description: Design practice that uses the sun's energy to heat and cool buildings, reducing the need for mechanical systems

entities.name: RAINWATER HARVESTING
entities.description: Practice of collecting and using rainwater for various household purposes, reducing reliance on municipal water supplies

entities.name: GREEN ROOFS
entities.description: Roofing systems covered with vegetation, which provide insulation, reduce heat island effect, and manage stormwater

relations: Mesopotamia is one of the ancient civilizations where homes served as centers of social, political, and religious life
Egypt is one of the ancient civilizations where homes served as centers of social, political, and religious life
Greece is one of the ancient civilizations where homes served as centers of social, political, and religious life
The Industrial Revolution marked a shift from the grand, fortified manor houses of the Middle Ages to more standardized and affordable housing
The Industrial Revolution laid the groundwork for technological advancements that eventually led to the development of smart technology in homes

Le Corbusier was a key figure in the modernist movement, influencing the design of homes and buildings around the world
Le Corbusier was a key figure in the modernist movement, which influenced the design of homes and buildings around the world

Frank Lloyd Wright was a key figure in the modernist movement, influencing the design of homes and buildings around the world
Frank Lloyd Wright was a key figure in the modernist movement, which influenced the design of homes and buildings around the world

Ludwig Mies van der Rohe was a key figure in the modernist movement, influencing the design of homes and buildings around the world
Ludwig Mies van der Rohe was a key figure in the modernist movement, which influenced the design of homes and buildings around the world
Levittown set the standard for the suburban home, which became a symbol of the American Dream in the post-World War II period
Smart technology has transformed the modern home, allowing for remote control and monitoring of various home systems
Smart homes are equipped with interconnected devices and systems that allow for remote control and monitoring of various aspects of the home
Sustainable design practices have become increasingly important in the design and construction of modern homes, aiming to reduce environmental impact and create healthier living environments
Sustainable homes are designed and constructed using sustainable practices to reduce environmental impact and create healthier living environments
Passive solar design is a key practice in the design of sustainable homes, using the sun's energy to heat and cool buildings
Rainwater harvesting is a practice used in sustainable homes to collect and use rainwater for various household purposes
Green roofs are a feature of sustainable homes, providing insulation, reducing heat island effect, and managing stormwater
